Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or sources to support the statement that the son-in-law of the president met with Russian officials at the Trump Tower after having them come in the back door.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the meeting between the son-in-law of the president and Russian officials at Trump Tower was suspicious or inappropriate without providing further context or evidence.
Exist alternative explanation: There may be alternative explanations or interpretations of the meeting between the son-in-law of the president and Russian officials, such as establishing communication between the new administration and the Russian government.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the meeting between the son-in-law of the president and Russian officials at Trump Tower was acknowledged by the White House and reported by The New York Times.
Falters at times: The claim may falter in terms of accurately representing the nature and circumstances of the meeting between the son-in-law of the president and Russian officials at Trump Tower.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the significance or implications of the son-in-law's meeting with Russian officials by suggesting suspicious or secretive behavior.
Understate: The claim may understate or downplay any potential innocence or legitimate reasons behind the meeting between the son-in-law of the president and Russian officials.
